he lies speechless, how he will point you readily to all the
boxes, and when he is past all memory, as the gossips guess,
then thinks he of forfeitures and obligations, nay when to all
men's hearings he whirls and rattles in the throat he is busy
threatening his poor Tenants? and this would last me now
some seven years thinking or thereabouts? but, I have a
Conceit acoming in picture upon this, I draw it myself,
which I'faith la I will present to your honour, you shall not chose
but like it for your Lordship shall give me nothing for it,
Nay you mistake me then,
For I am published bountiful enough,
Let us taste of your conceit.
In picture my Lord.
Aye, in picture.
Marry this it is ------ A usuring Father to be boiling in hell
and his son and Heir with a Whore dancing over him.
Has pared him to the quick.
The conceit is pretty I'faith,
But take it upon my life it will never be liked.
No, why I am sure the whore will be liked well enough.
Aye if she were out of the picture he would like her then himself.
And as for the son and heir, he shall be an eyesore to
no young Revellers, for he shall be drawn in cloth-of-gold
breeches.
If thou hast put my meaning in the pockets,
And canst not draw that out, my thought was this,
To see the picture of a usuring father
Boiling in hell, our rich men would never like it,
O true cry you heartily mercy, I know the reason, for
some of them had rather be damned indeed, than damned in colours.
A parlous melancholy, has wit enough,
To murder any man, and I will give him means,
I think thou art ill moneyed;
Money, ho, ho,
it has been my want so long, it is now my scoff.
I have even forgot what colour silver is of.
It hits as I could wish,
I get good cloths,
Of those that dread my humour, and for table room,
I feed on those that can not be rid of me,
Somewhat to set thee up withal,
O mine eyes,
How now man?
Almost struck blind,
This bright unusual shine, to me seems proud,
I dare not look till the sun be in a cloud,
I think I shall affect his melancholy,
How are they now.
The better for your asking.
You shall be better yet if you but fasten,
Truly on my intent, now you are both present
I will unbrace such a close private villain,
Unto your vengeful swords, the like never heard of,
Who hath disgraced you much and injured us,
Disgraced us my Lord?
Aye Hippolito.
I kept it here till now that both your angers,
Might meet him at once,
I am covetous,
To know the villain,
You know him that slave Pander,
Piato whom we threatened last
With irons perpetual prisonment;
All this is I.
Is it he my Lord?
I will tell you, you first preferred him to me.
Did you brother.
I did indeed?
And the ingrateful villain,
To quit that kindness, strongly wrought with me,
Being as you see a likely man for pleasure,
With jewels to corrupt your virgin sister.
o villain,
He shall surely die that did it.
I far from thinking any Virgin harm.
Especially knowing her to be as chaste
As that part which scarce suffers to be touched,
The eye would not endure him,
Would you not my Lord,
it was wondrous honourably done,
But with some five frowns kept him out,
Out slave.
What did me he but in revenge of that,
Went of his own free will to make infirm,
Your sisters honour, whom I honour with my soul,
For chaste respect, and not prevailing there,
(As it was but desperate folly to attempt it,)
In mere spleen, by the way, waylays your mother,
Whose honour being a coward as it seems.
Yielded by little force.
Coward indeed.
He proud of their advantage, (as he thought)
Brought me these news for happy, but I, heaven forgive me for it .
What did your honour.
In rage pushed him from me,
Trampled beneath his throat, spurned him, and bruised:
Indeed I was too cruel to say troth.
Most Nobly managed.
Has not heaven an ear? Is all the lightning wasted?
If I now were so impatient in a modest cause,
What should you be?
Full mad, he shall not live
To see the Moon change.
He is about the Palace,
Hippolito entice him this way, that thy brother
May take full mark of him.
Heart? -- that shall not need my Lord,
I can direct him so far.
Yet for my hates sake,
Go, wind him this way? I will see him bleed myself.
What now brother?
Nay even what you will -- you are put to it brother?
An impossible task, I will swear,
To bring him hither, that is already here.
Thy name, I have forgot it?
Vindice my Lord.
it is a good name that.
Aye, a Revenger.
It does betoken courage, thou shouldst be valiant,
And kill thine enemies.
That is my hope my Lord.
This slave is one.
I will doom him.
Then I will praise thee?
Do thou observe me best, and I will best raise thee.
Indeed, I thank you.
Now Hippolito, where is the slave Pander?
Your good Lordship,
Would have a loathsome sight of him, much offensive?
He is not in case now to be seen my Lord,
The worst of all the deadly sins is in him:
That beggarly damnation, drunkenness.
Then he is a double slave.
It was well conveyed, upon a sudden wit.
What, are you both,
Firmly resolved, I will see him dead myself.
Or else, let not us live.
You may direct your brother to take note of him.
I shall.
Rise but in this, and you shall never fall.
Your honours Vassals.
This was wisely carried,
Deep policy in us, makes fools of such:
Then must a slave die, when he knows too much.
O thou almighty patience, it is my wonder,
That such a fellow, impudent and wicked,
Should not be cloven as he stood:
Or with a secret wind burst open!
Is there no thunder left, or is it kept up
In stock for heavier vengeance, there it goes!
Brother we lose ourselves
But I have found it,
It will hold, it is sure, thanks, thanks to any spirit,
That mingled it amongst my inventions.
What is it?
it is sound, and good, thou shalt partake it,
I am hired to kill myself.
True.
Prithee mark it,
And the old Duke being dead, but not conveyed,
For he is already missed too, and you know:
Murder will peep out of the closest husk.
Most true?
What say you then to this device,
If we dressed up the body of the Duke.
In that disguise of yours.
You are quick, you have reached it.
I like it wondrously.
And being in drink, as you have published him,
To lean him on his elbow, as if sleep had caught him:
Which claims most interest in such sluggy men.
Good yet, but here is a doubt,
Methought by the Dukes son to kill that pander,
Shall when he is known be thought to kill the Duke.
Neither, O thanks, it is substantial
For that disguise being on him, which I wore,
It will be thought I, which he calls the Pander, did kill the Duke,
and fled away in his apparel, leaving him so disguised, to avoid
swift pursuit
Firmer, and firmer.
Nay doubt not it is in grain, I warrant it hold colour.
Let us about it.
But, by the way too, now I think of it, brother,
Let us conjure that base devil out of our Mother.

stage.l: Enter the Dutches arme in arme with the Bastard: he seemeth lasciuiously
to her, after them, Enter Superuacuo, running with a rapier,

sp.l: Madam, unlock yourself, should it be seen,
Your arm would be suspected.
Who is it that dares suspect, or this, or these?
May not we deal our favours where we please?
I am, confident, you may.
'sfoot brother hold.
Would't let the Bastard shame us?
Hold, hold, brother? there is fitter time than now.
Now when I see it.
it is too much seen already.
Seen and known,
The Nobler she is, the baser is she grown.
If she were bent lasciviously, the fault
Of mighty women, that sleep soft, -- O death,
Must she needs choose such an unequal sinner:
To make all worse.
A Bastard, the Dukes Bastard, Shame heaped on shame.
O our disgrace.
Most women have small waste the world through-out,
But their desires are thousand miles about.
Come stay not here, let us after, and prevent,
Or else they will sin faster than we will repent.

stage.l: Enter Vindice and Hippolito, bringing out their Mother
one by one shoulder, and the other by the other, with

sp.l: O thou? for whom no name is bad enough
What means my sons what will you murder me?
Wicked unnatural Parents.
Fiend of women.
o! are sons turned monsters? help.
In vain.
Are you so barbarous to set Iron nipples
Upon the breast that gave you suck.
That breast,
Is turned to Quarled poison.
Cut not your days for it, am not I your mother?
Thou dost usurp that title now by fraud
For in that shell of mother breeds a bawd.
A bawd? O name far loathsomer than hell.
It should be so knewest thou thy Office well.
I hate it.
Ah is it possible, Thou only, you powers on hie,
That women should dissemble when they die.
Dissemble.
Did not the Dukes son direct
A fellow, of the worlds condition, hither,
That did corrupt all that was good in thee:
Made thee uncivilly forget thyself,
And work our sister to his lust.
Who I,
That had been monstrous? I defy that man:
For any such intent, none lives so pure,
But shall be soiled with slander, -- good son believe it not.
o I am in doubt,
Whether I am myself, or no,
Stay, let me look again upon this face.
Who shall be saved when mothers have no grace.
It would make one half despair.
I was the man,
Defy me, now? let us see, do it modestly.
O hell unto my soul.
In that disguise, I sent from the Dukes son,
Tried you, and found you base metal,
As any villain might have done.
O no, no tongue but yours could have bewitched me so.
O nimble in damnation, quick in tune,
There is no devil could strike fire so soon:
I am confuted in a word.
o sons, forgive me, to myself I will prove more true,
You that should honour me, I kneel to you.
A mother to give aim to her own daughter.
True brother, how far beyond nature it is,
Though many Mothers do it.
Nay if you draw tears once, go you to bed,
Wet will make iron blush and change to red:
Brother it rains, it will spoil your dagger, house it.
it is done.
i'faith it is a sweet shower, it does much good.
The fruitful grounds, and meadows of her soul,
Has been long dry: power down thou blessed dew,
Rise Mother, troth this shower has made you higher.
O you heavens? take this infectious spot out of my soul,
I will rinse it in seven waters of mine eyes?
Make my tears salt enough to taste of grace,
To weep, is to our sex: naturally given:
But to weep truly that is a gift from heaven?
Nay I will kiss you now: kiss her brother?
Let us marry her to our souls, wherein is no lust,
And honourably love her.
Let it be.
For honest women are so seld and rare,
it is good to cherish those poor few that are.
o you of easy wax, do but imagine
Now the disease has left you, how leprously
That Office would have clinged unto your forehead,
All mothers that had any graceful hue,
Would have worn masks to hide their face at you:
It would have grown to this, at your foul name;
Green-coloured maids would have turned red with shame?
And then our sister full of hire, and baseness.
There had been boiling lead again,
The dukes sons great Concubine:
A drab of State, a cloth-of-silver slut,
To have her train borne up, and her soul trail in the dirt; great.
To be miserably great, rich to be eternally wretched.
O common madness:
Ask but the thrivingest harlot in cold blood,
She would give the world to make her honour good,
Perhaps you will say but only to the Dukes son,
In private; why, she first begins with one,
Who afterward to thousand proves a whore:
"Break Ice in one place, it will crack in more."
Most certainly applied?
o Brother, you forget our business.
And well remembered, joy is a subtle elf,
I think man is happiest, when he forgets himself:
Farewell once dried, now holy-watered Mead,
Our hearts wear Feathers, that before wore Lead.
I will give you this, that one I never knew
Plead better, for, and against the Devil, than you.
You make me proud of it.
Commend us in all virtue to our Sister.
Aye for the love of heaven, to that true maid.
With my best words.
Why that was motherly said.
I wonder now what fury did transport me?
I feele good thoughts begin to settle in me.
o with what fore-head can I look on her?
Whose honour I have so impiously beset,
And here she comes,
Now mother, you have wrought with me so strongly,
That what for my advancement, as to calm
The trouble of your tongue: I am content.
Content, to what?
To do as you have wished me,
To prostitute my breast to the Dukes son:
And to put myself to common Usury.
I hope you will not so.
Hope you I will not?
That is not the hope you look to be saved in.
Truth but it is.
Do not deceive yourself,
I am, as you even out of Marble wrought,
What would you now, are ye not pleased yet with me,
You shall not wish me to be more lascivious
than I intend to be.
Strike not me cold,
How often have you charged me on your blessing
To be a cursed woman -- when you knew,
Your blessing had no force to make me lewd,
You laid your curse upon me, that did more,
The mothers curse is heavy, where that fights,
Sons set in storm,and daughters lose their lights?
Good child, dear maid, if there be any spark
Of heavenly intellectual fire within thee, o let my breath,
Revive it to a flame:
Put not all out, with woman's wilful follies,
I am recovered of that foul disease
That haunts too many mothers, kind forgive me,
Make me not sick in health? -- if then
My words prevailed when they were wickedness,
How much more now when they are just and good?
I wonder what you mean, are not you she
For whose infect persuasions I could scarce
Kneel out my prayers, and had much ado
In three hours reading, to untwist so much
Of the black serpent, as you wound about me.
It is unfruitful, held tedious to repeat what is past,
I am now your present Mother.
Push, now it is too late,
Bethink again, thou knowest not what thou sayst.
No, deny advancement, treasure, the Dukes son.
O see, I spoke those words, and now they poison me:
What will the deed do then?
Advancement, true: as high as shame can pitch,
For Treasure; whoever knew a harlot rich?
Or could build by the purchase of her sin,
An hospital to keep their bastards in: The Dukes son,
o when women are young Courtiers, they are sure to be old beggars,
To know the miseries most harlots taste,
Thou wouldst wish thyself unborn, when thou art unchaste.
O mother let me twine about your neck,
And kiss you till my soul melt on your lips,
I did but this to try you.
O speak truth.
Indeed I did not, for no tongue has force to alter me from honest
If maidens would, men's words could have no power,
A virgin honour is a crystal Tower.
Which being weak is guarded with good spirits,
Until she basely yields no ill inherits.
O happy child! faith and thy birth hath saved me,
Amongst thousand daughters happiest of all others,
Buy thou a glass for maids, and I for mothers.
So, so, he leans well, take heed you wake him not brother
I warrant you my life for yours.
That is a good lay, for I must kill myself?
Brother that is I: that sits for me: do you mark it,
And I must stand ready here to make away myself yonder -- I
must sit to be killed, and stand to kill myself, I could vary it
not so little as thrice over again,
it has some eight returns like
Michaelmas Term.
that is enough a conscience.
But sirrah does the Dukes son come single?
No there is the hell of it, his faith is too feeble to go alone?
he brings flesh-flies after him, that will buzz against supper
time, and hum for his coming out.
Ah the fly-flop of vengeance beat them to pieces? here
was the sweetest occasion, the fittest hour, to have made my
revenge familiar with him, show him the body of the Duke his
father, and how quaintly he died like a Politician in hugger-mugger,
made no man acquainted with it, and in Catastrophe
slain him over his fathers breast,
and o I am mad to lose such a
sweet opportunity.
Nay push, prithee be content! there is no remedy present,
may not hereafter times open in as fair faces as this.
They may if they can paint so well?
Come, now to avoid all suspicion, let us forsake this room,
and be going to meet the Dukes son.
Content, I am for any weather? heart step close, here he comes?
My honoured Lord?
o me; you both present.
Even newly my Lord, just as your Lordship entered now?
about this place we had notice given he should be, but in some
loathsome plight or other.
Came your honour private?
Private enough for this:
only a few
Attend my coming out.
Death rot those few.
Stay yonder is the slave.
Mass there is the slave indeed my Lord;
It is a good child, he calls his Father slave.
Aye, that is the villain, the damned villain: softly,
Tread easy.
Puh, I warrant you my Lord, we will stifle in our breaths.
That will do well:
Base rogue, thou sleepest thy last, it is policy,
To have him killed in his sleep, for if he waked
he would betray all to them.
But my Lord.
Ha, what sayst?
Shall we kill him now he is drunk?
Aye best of all.
Why then he will never live to be sober?
No matter, let him reel to hell.
But being so full of liquor, I fear he will put out all the fire,
Thou art a mad breast.
And leave none to warm your Lordships Golls withal;
For he that dies drunk, falls into hell-fire like a Bucket of water,
qush, qush.
Come be ready, nake your swords, think of your wrongs
This slave has injured you.
Troth so he has, and he has paid well for it.
meet with him now.
you will bear us out my Lord?
Puh, am I a Lord for nothing think you, quickly, now.
Sa, sa, sa: thump, there he lies.
Nimbly done, ha? o, villains, murderers,
It is the old Duke my father.
That is a jest.
What stiff and cold already?
O pardon me to call you from your names:
It is none of your deed, -- that villain Piato
Whom you thought now to kill, has murdered him,
And left him thus disguised.
And not unlikely.
O rascal was he not ashamed,
To put the Duke into a greasy doublet.
He has been cold and stiff who knows, how long?
Marry that do I.
No words I pray, of anything intended:
o my Lord.
I would fain have your Lordship think that we have
small reason to prate.
Faith thou sayst true? I will forth-with send to Court,
For all the Nobles, Bastard, Duchess, all?
How here by miracle we found him dead,
And in his raiment that foul villain fled.
That will be the best way my Lord, to clear us all: let us
cast about to be clear.
Ho, Nencio, Sordido, and the rest.
My Lord.
My Lord.
Be witnesses of a strange spectacle:
Choosing for private conference that sad room
We found the Duke my father gealed in blood.
My Lord the Duke -- run hie thee Nencio,
Startle the Court by signifying so much.
Thus much by wit a deep Revenger can:
When murder is known, to be the clearest man
We are farthest off, and with as bold an eye,
Survey his body as the standers-by.
My royal father, too basely let blood,
By a malevolent slave.
Hark? he calls thee slave again.
He has lost, he may.
o sight, look hither, see, his lips are gnawn with poison.
How -- his lips by the mass they be.
O villain - O rogue -- O slave -- O rascal:
O good deceit, he quits him with like terms.
Where.
Which way.
Over what roof hangs this prodigious Comet,
In deadly fire.
Behold, behold my Lords the Duke my father is murdered
by a vassal, that owes this habit, and here left disguised.
My Lord and husband.
Reverend Majesty.
I have seen these cloths, often attending on him.
That Nobleman, has been in the Country, for he does not lie?
Learn of our mother let us dissemble too.
I am glad he is vanished; so I hope are you?
Aye you may take my word for it.
Old Dad, dead?
Aye, one of his cast sins will send the Fates
Most hearty commendations by his own son,
I will tug the new stream, till strength be done.
Where be those two, that did affirm to us?
My Lord the Duke was privately rid forth?
O pardon us my Lords, he gave that charge
upon our lives if he were missed at Court,
To answer so; he rode not anywhere,
we left him private with that fellow here?
Confirmed.
O heavens, that false charge was his death,
Impudent Beggars, durst you to our face,
Maintain such a false answer? bear him straight to execution.
My Lord?
Urge me no more.
In this excuse, may be called half the murther?
You have sentenced well.
Away see it be done.
Could you not stick: see what confession doth?
Who would not lie when men are hanged for truth?
Brother how happy is our vengeance.
Why it hits, past the apprehension of indifferent wits.
My Lord let post horse be sent,
Into all places to entrap the villain,
Post horse ha ha.
My Lord, we are something bold to know our duty?
Your father is accidentally departed,
The titles that were due to him, meet you.
Meet me? I am not at leisure my good Lord,
I have many griefs to dispatch out of the way:
Welcome sweet titles, -- talk to me my Lords,
Of sepulchres, and mighty emperors bones,
That is thought for me.
So, one may see by this,
How foreign markets go:
Courtiers have feet of the nines, and tongues of the twelves,
They flatter Dukes and Dukes flatter themselves.
My Lord it is your shine must comfort us.
Alas I shine in tears like the Sun in April.
You are now my Lords grace?
My Lords grace? I perceive you will have it so.
It is but your own.
Then heavens give me grace to be so?
He prays well for himself.
Madam all sorrows,
Must run their circles into joys, no doubt but time,
Will make the murderer bring forth himself.
He were an Ass then i'faith?
In the mean season,
Let us bethink the latest funeral honours:
Due to the Dukes cold body, -- and withal,
Calling to memory our new happiness,
Spread in his royal son, -- Lords Gentlemen,
Prepare for Revels.
Revels.
Time hath several falls,
Griefs lift up joys, feasts put down funerals.
Come then my Lords, my favours to you all,
The Duchess is suspected, foully bent,
I will begin Dukedom with her banishment?
Revels.
Aye, that is the word, we are firm yet,
Strike one strain more, and then we crown our wit.
Well, have the fairest mark, -- (so said the Duke when
he begot me,)
And if I miss his heart or near about,
Then have at any, a Bastard scorns to be out.
Notest thou that Spurio brother.
Yes I note him to our shame.
He shall not live, his hair shall not grow much longer?
in this time of Revels tricks may be set afoot; seest thou yon
new Moon, it shall outlive the new Duke by much, this hand
shall dispossess him, then we are mighty.
A mask is treasons licence, that build upon?
It is murders best face when a vizard is on.
is it so? it is very good,
And do you think to be Duke then, kind brother:
I will see fair play, drop one, and there lies the other.

stage.l: Enter Vindice and Hippolito, with Piero and other Lords.

sp.l: My Lords; be all of Music, strike old griefs into other countries
That flow in too much milk, and have faint livers,
Not daring to stab home their discontents:
Let our hid flames break out, as fire, as lightning,
To blast this villainous Dukedom: vexed with sin;
Wind up your souls to their full height again.
How?
Which way?
Any way: our wrongs are such,
We can not justly be revenged too much.
You shall have all enough: ---- Revels are toward,
And those few Nobles that have long suppressed you,
Are busied to the furnishing of a Mask:
And do affect to make a pleasant tail of it,
The Masking suites are fashioning, now comes in
That which must glad us all -- we to take pattern
Of all those suites, the colour, trimming, fashion,
Even to an undistinguished hair almost:
Then entering first, observing the true form,
Within a strain or two we shall find leisure,
To steal our swords out handsomely,
And when they think their pleasure sweet and good,
In midst of all their joys, they shall sigh blood.
Weightily, effectually.
Before the other Maskers come.
We are gone, all done and past.
But how for the Dukes guard?
Let that alone,
By one and one their strengths shall be drunk down,
There are five hundred Gentlemen in the action,
That will apply themselves, and not stand idle.
o let us hug your bosoms.
Come my Lords,
Prepare for deeds, let other times have words.

stage.l: In a dum shew, the possessing of the young Duke.
with all his Nobles: Then sounding Musick.
A furnisht Table is brought forth: then enters the Duke
and his Nobles to the banquet. A blasing star appeareth.

sp.l: Many harmonious hours, and choicest pleasures,
Fill up the royal numbers of your years.
My Lords we are pleased to thank you? -- though we know,
it is but your duty now to wish it so.
That shine makes us all happy.
His Grace frowns?
Yet we must say he smiles.
I think we must.
That foul Incontinent Duchess we have banished,
The Bastard shall not live: after these Revels
I will begin strange ones; he and the stepsons,
Shall pay their lives for the first subsidies,
we must not frown so soon, else it had been now?
My gracious Lord please you prepare for pleasure,
The mask is not far off.
we are for pleasure,
Beshrew thee, what art thou? madest me start?
Thou hast committed treason, -- A blazing star.
A blazing star, O where my Lord.
Spy out.
See, see, my Lords, a wondrous dreadful one.
I am not pleased at that ill-knotted fire,
That bushing flaring star, -- am not I Duke?
It should not quake me now: had it appeared,
Before it, I might then have justly feared,
But yet they say, whom art and learning Weds:
When stars wear locks, they threaten great men's heads,
Is it so? you are read my Lords.
May it please your Grace,
It shows great anger.
That does not please our Grace.
Yet here is the comfort my Lord, many times
When it seems most it threatens farthest off.
Faith and I think so too.
Beside my Lord,
You are gracefully established with the loves
Of all your subjects: and for natural death,
I hope it will be threescore years acoming.
True, no more but threescore years.
Fourscore I hope my Lord:
And fivescore, I,
But it is my hope my Lord, you shall never die.
Give me thy hand, these others I rebuke,
He that hopes so, is fittest for a Duke:
Thou shalt sit next me, take your places Lords,
we are ready now for sports, let them set on.
You thing? we shall forget you quite anon!
I hear them coming my Lord.

stage.l: Enter the Maske of Reuengers the two Brothers, and two Lords more.

sp.l: Ah it is well,
Brothers, and Bastard, you dance next in hell?

stage.l: At the end, steale out their swords, and these foure kill the foure at
the Table, in their Chaires It thunders.

sp.l: Mark, Thunder?
Dost know thy cue, thou big-voiced crier?
Dukes groans, are thunders watch-words.
So my Lords, You have enough.
Come let us away, no lingering.
Follow, go?
No power is angry when the lustful die,
When thunder claps, heaven likes the tragedy.
o, o.

stage.l: Enter the other Maske of entended murderers? Step-sons; Bastard;
and a fourth man, comming in dauncing, the Duke recouers a
little in voyce, and groanes, -- calls a guard, treason.
At which they all start out of their measure, and turning towards
the Table, they finde them all to be murdered.

sp.l: Whose groan was that?
Treason, a guard.
How now? all murdered!
Murdered!
And those his Nobles?
Here is a labour saved,
I thought to have sped him, 'sblood how came this.
Then I proclaim myself, now I am Duke.
Thou Duke,! brother thou liest.
Slave so dost thou?
Base villain hast thou slain my Lord and Master.
Pistols, treason, murder, help, guard my Lord the Duke.
Lay hold upon this Traitors?
o.
Alas, the Duke is murdered.
And the Nobles.
Surgeons, Surgeons, -- heart does he breath so long.
A piteous tragædie, able to wake,
An old man's eyes blood-shot;
o.
Look to my lord the Duke - a vengeance throttle him.
Confess thou murderous and unhallowed man,
Didst thou kill all these?
None but the Bastard I,
How came the Duke slain then;
We found him so,
O villain,
Hark.
Those in the mask did murder us,
Law you now sir.
O marble impudence! will you confess now?
'Sloud it is all false,
Away with that foul monster,
Dipped in a Princes blood.
Heart it is a lie,
Let him have bitter execution.
New marrow no I can not be expressed,
How fairs my Lord the Duke.
Farewell to all,
He that climes highest has the greatest fall,
My tongue is out of office.
Air Gentlemen, air,
Now thou wilt not prate of it, it was Vindice murdered thee,
o.
Murdered thy Father.
o.
And I am he - tell no-body, so so, the Duke is departed,
It was a deadly hand that wounded him,
The rest, ambitious who should rule and sway,
After his death were so made all away,
My Lord was unlikely,
Now the hope,
Of Italy lies in your reverend years?
Your hair, will make the silver age again,
When there was fewer but more honest men,
The burden is weighty and will press age down,
May I so rule that heaven nay keep the crown,
The rape of your good Lady has been quited,
With death on death.
Just is the Law above
But of all things it puts me most to wonder,
How the old Duke came murdered.
o, my Lord.
It was the strangeliest carried, I not hard of the like,
It was all done for the best my Lord,
All for your graces good? we may be bold to speak it now,
It was some-what witty carried though we say it.
It was we two murdered him,
You two?
None else I'faith my Lord nay it was well managed,
Lay hands upon those villains.
How? on us?
Bear them to speedy execution,
Heart was it not for your good my Lord?
My good away with them such an old man as he,
You that would murder him would murder me,
Is it come about;
'sfoot brother you begun,
May not we set as well as the Dukes son,
Thou hast no conscience, are we not revenged?
Is there one enemy left alive amongst those?
It is time to die, when we are ourselves our foes.
When murders shut deeds close, this curse does seal them,
If none disclose them they themselves reveal them!
This murder might have slept in tongueless brass,
But for ourselves, and the world died an ass;
Now I remember too, here was Piato
Brought forth a knavish sentence once, no doubt (said he) but time
Will make the murderer bring forth himself?
It is well he died, he was a witch,
And now my Lord, since we are in for ever:
This work was ours which else might have been slipped,
And if we list, we could have Nobles clipped,
And go for less than beggars, but we hate
To bleed so cowardly we have enough,
i'faith, we are well, our Mother turned, our Sister true,
We die after a nest of Dukes. adieu,
How subtly was that murder closed, bear up,
Those tragic bodies, it is a heavy season:
Pray heaven their blood may wash away all treason.
